title: Question 76

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for worsening erythema and pruritus that began 3 days ago. Ten days ago, bacitracin ointment was used following excision of a dysplastic nevus on his upper back; it was stopped 3 days ago. Two weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Contact dermatitis is an eczematous eruption that occurs at the site of allergen contact with the skin and is characterized by pruritic, erythematous patches or plaques that may show vesicles and weeping acutely, or dry scaling and lichenification at later stages. Although the patient discontinued using bacitracin 3 days before presenting, erythema and pruritus persist and would be best treated with a topical glucocorticoid, such as triamcinolone cream. Bacitracin, polymyxin B, and neomycin are common topical antibiotics used to treat or prevent wound infections and are frequently associated with allergic contact dermatitis. For clean wounds, such as a skin surgical site, the application of plain petrolatum is recommended over the use of topical antibiotics.
